content.value: This page chronicles the rich history of chess in Victoria by showcasing every titleholder of the Victorian Chess Championship. From its early pioneers to modern-day masters, each champion listed here has left a lasting mark on the state’s chess legacy. Explore the names, years, and remarkable achievements that together tell the story of Victorian chess excellence.

This page celebrates the champions of the prestigious Australasian Masters tournament, a pinnacle event in the region’s chess calendar. From its earliest contests to recent triumphs, these champions represent the highest level of skill and dedication in Australasian chess. Discover the players, years, and memorable victories that define this remarkable tradition.

content.value: The
Melbourne Chess Club (MCC)
, founded in
, is one of Australia’s—and the Southern Hemisphere’s—oldest continuously operating chess clubs. Located at
66 Leicester Street, Fitzroy

, MCC is a volunteer-run, not-for-profit organisation dedicated to promoting chess for players of all ages and skill levels. The club reinvests all its revenue into improving facilities, running events, and nurturing its vibrant chess community.
The
Melbourne Chess Club (MCC)
, founded in
, is one of Australia’s—and the Southern Hemisphere’s—oldest continuously operating chess clubs. Located at
66 Leicester Street, Fitzroy

, MCC is a volunteer-run, not-for-profit organisation dedicated to promoting chess for players of all ages and skill levels. The club reinvests all its revenue into improving facilities, running events, and nurturing its vibrant chess community.
The club meets at 21a Electra Avenue on Friday nights and Sunday afternoons. Rated tournaments are organised for both sessions throughout the year.
The club meets at 21a Electra Avenue on Friday nights and Sunday afternoons. Rated tournaments are organised for both sessions throughout the year.

The club actively supports the development of junior chess through its junior organization Canterbury Junior Chess Club inc. New members and visitors are welcome at the club and membership and tournament fees are kept at a reasonable level.
The clubs premises are spacious, modern and well lit with plenty of parking, areas for children to run around and accompanying persons to sit and relax
Tea, coffee and light refreshments at moderate prices are available.
The club is affiliated with Chess Victoria.
The club maintains extensive programmes for Friday and Sunday tournaments. Members and visitors are welcome to all our events.
All events have an entry fee with club members eligible for a discount.
If you apply for membership part-way through our financial year then your subscription may be reduced pro-rata
Individual events held at the Club are also subject to an entry fee which includes a Chess Victoria registration fee if they are rated.
Hobsons Bay Chess Club, based in Altona in Western Melbourne, has been promoting chess since 1974 and prides itself on being
multicultural and community-oriented

. Members hail from diverse backgrounds—Australia, Greece, Germany, Italy, Hungary, the Philippines, Ukraine, Macedonia, China, Chile—and include players aged from 8 to over 60, demonstrating how chess has the power to unify individuals across age and heritage

Why Hobsons Bay Chess Club is the Right Choice Now
1. Proven Capability – Recent Success

Hobsons Bay Chess Club (HBCC) successfully hosted the 2025 Victorian Junior Chess Championship, demonstrating our organisational strength, volunteer base, and technical expertise to deliver a high-profile statewide junior event at a professional standard.

The championship attracted a record number of participants, showcasing both the growth of junior chess in Victoria and HBCC’s ability to manage large-scale events. For the first time in Victorian Junior history, demand was so high that juniors had to be placed on a waitlist. This is clear evidence of the unprecedented growth of chess in the west, and HBCC’s unique role in driving that expansion.

Our tournaments also secured sponsorship from Bacchus Marsh Grammar, introduced event merchandise such as t-shirts, and engaged local politicians to officiate. This demonstrates our capacity to deliver events that not only serve the chess community but also attract broader community and institutional support.
2. Run by Professional Event Organisers
HBCC benefits from a diverse team of professionals with experience across multiple industries:
Experienced Arbiters providing authoritative event oversight,
Senior IT professionals from federal and multinational companies applying Agile and PMBOK methodologies to planning and delivery.
This mix of skills ensures our tournaments are organised with the discipline, structure, and professionalism of major corporate projects — an approach rarely matched at the club level.
3. Geographic Expansion and Accessibility

For decades, junior chess has been concentrated in Melbourne’s eastern suburbs. Awarding the Junior Championship to HBCC ensures fairer statewide access, particularly for families and schools in the west who have historically been under-served.

The western corridor is one of Victoria’s fastest-growing regions, with a significant South Asian demographic where chess is culturally embedded and increasingly popular — amplified by Gukesh’s recent World Championship victory.

This is not merely a trend but a demographic reality. The most common surname in Australia is Singh, reflecting the South Asian community’s prominence. In South Asia, chess is a national pastime second only to cricket.

HBCC is ideally positioned to harness this momentum, bringing new families and communities into Victorian chess. The west of Melbourne is the largest untapped market — as proven by Northern Star events in Sydney attracting 600+ players.
4. Strong Junior Development Pipeline
HBCC delivers a year-round junior program that supports players at every stage:
Rookies & Mini Tournaments – stepping stones for beginners,
Weekly classical events – competitive pathways for developing players,
ACF and FIDE rated events – recognition at state, national, and international levels.

From the 2025 Victorian Juniors, HBCC players dominated the event, securing top 3 places in all age categories. This holistic program nurtures both grassroots participation and elite performance, ensuring sustainability in junior chess growth.
5. Preventing a Monopoly on Junior Tournaments

For the past 12 years, the Victorian Juniors have been organised solely by Box Hill Chess Club. While their contribution is acknowledged, continuing this arrangement risks creating a monopoly of major junior events.
Awarding the Juniors to HBCC introduces balance, fairness, and shared opportunity, ensuring a healthier and more diverse chess ecosystem across Victoria.
6. Innovation and Modernisation

HBCC is at the forefront of digital innovation in tournament management, employing online pairings, live results, and integrated platforms for families and participants. This creates transparency, global visibility, and a professional event experience. (See our website for examples.)
7. Diversity and Community Impact

HBCC is proud to serve one of Victoria’s most culturally diverse communities. By engaging with schools and multicultural groups, we create opportunities for families who may not otherwise access organised chess.
Awarding the Junior Championship to HBCC would highlight Chess Victoria’s commitment to equity, inclusion, and statewide development.
8. Volunteer and Arbiter Development
Major tournaments are essential for training the next generation of organisers and arbiters. To date, these opportunities have been concentrated at a single club.
By awarding the Juniors to HBCC, volunteers and arbiters in the west will gain vital experience, building a broader and more sustainable administrative base for Victorian chess.
9. A Stepping Stone to Larger Events

Delivering the Victorian Juniors with excellence positions HBCC to host larger tournaments in future, including subcontinental or international junior events. This would raise Victoria’s profile on the global chess stage and open new opportunities for Chess Victoria to showcase its leadership.
10. Commitment by Sponsor
Bacchus Marsh Grammar (BMG) has committed to providing a larger venue to cater for the continued expansion in player numbers.
Conclusion
While Box Hill Chess Club’s junior program is unmatched in its legacy, Hobsons Bay Chess Club represents the future of junior chess in Victoria.
We bring:
A proven record with the most recent Victorian Juniors,
A professional organising team with cross-industry expertise,
A dedicated junior pipeline producing results at every level,
A strategic location expanding opportunities in Melbourne’s west,
And a commitment to diversity, innovation, volunteer growth, and international ambition.

Awarding the Victorian Junior Championship to Hobsons Bay Chess Club will not only maintain Victoria’s tradition of excellence but also expand access, strengthen inclusion, and secure the long-term future of junior chess across the state.

subTitle.en-US: The most popular chess club in Victoria

content.value: Chess Victoria is the official governing body for chess in Victoria, Australia. We oversee the promotion, development, and regulation of chess throughout the state. Our role includes organizing official state championships, supporting local chess clubs and schools, training arbiters and coaches, and ensuring fair competition under internationally recognized rules. Whether you are a beginner, a parent looking to introduce chess to your child, or an experienced tournament player, Chess Victoria provides pathways to learn, play, and compete.

question.en-US: How can I get involved in chess in Victoria?

content.value: Join a local club:
Chess Victoria is affiliated with numerous clubs across metropolitan and regional areas, where players of all ages and skill levels meet regularly.
School chess programs:
Many schools run chess as part of their extracurricular activities, often with the help of accredited coaches.
Tournaments:
Players can participate in rated events ranging from junior competitions to open championships.
Volunteering and officiating:
Adults who wish to support the community can volunteer at events or undertake training to become accredited arbiters and coaches.

question.en-US: What kinds of tournaments are held in Victoria?

content.value: Chess Victoria oversees a wide range of tournaments throughout the year. These include:
Junior events:
Age-based competitions like the Victorian Junior Championship.
Open tournaments:
State-level events such as the Victorian Open and Victorian Championship.
Inter-school competitions:
Annual team-based events for primary and secondary schools.
Rapid and Blitz tournaments:
Faster formats for players who enjoy more dynamic games.

content.value: DUAL FORMAT
A dual-format tournament, the
MCC Classic
comprises (1) a 9 rounds round-robin event for the top 9 rated players + 2024 Qualifier, and (2) a 9 round Swiss open event for the rest of the field.
Tornelo Tournament Page
Location
Melbourne Chess Club - 66 Leicester St, Fitzroy
Format

9 Rounds Round-Robin Tournament for the top 9 FIDE rated players + 2024 Qualifier*
9 Rounds Swiss Open Tournament for the rest of the entered players
Both tournaments will be ACF and FIDE (
Round-Robin
and
Swiss
) rated

Round-Robin Entry Date and Swiss Eligibility
Round-Robin players must enter by Saturday 23 August 2025.

This is to allow the pairings for the Round-Robin Tournament to be set a day or so before Round 1.
A rating cap on Swiss entries at around the rating of the bottom seeded Round Robin player may be set for players registering after Saturday 23 August.
Time Control

90 minutes per game + 30 seconds per move.
Forfeit time is 30 minutes after the advertised start time.
Entry Fee

$90 Full Member, $80 Concession / Junior Member (add $15 for Non-Members)
Early bird discount of $10 if paid by Wednesday 20 August
Free entry for Club Member GMs/WGMs, IMs/WIMs and FMs/WFMs and non Victorian GMs/WGMs and IMs/WIMs.
If you want a round 1 bye (for the Swiss only) you must have have fully paid your entry to be paired. Refunds are available if notified 24 hours before the event.
Timetable

Round 1: Mon 25 Aug, 7.15pm
Round 2: Mon 1 Sep, 7.15pm
Round 3: Mon 8 Sep, 7.15pm
Round 4: Mon 15 Sep, 7.15pm
Round 5: Mon 22 Sep, 7.15pm
Round 6: Mon 29 Sep, 7.15pm
Round 7: Mon 6 Oct, 7.15pm
Round 8: Mon 13 Oct, 7.15pm
Round 9: Mon 20 Oct, 7.15pm
Byes (Swiss Open Tournament only)
Player may take up to two half point byes for rounds 1-7
Prizes
Round-Robin Tournament
Guaranteed!

)
1st:
Swiss Open Tournament

$1500 prize pool (Provisional)
Field will be divided into three prize divisions:
Prize category 1: 1st-$300 & 2nd-$200
Prize category 2: 1st-$300 & 2nd-$200
Prize category 3: 1st-$300 & 2nd-$200
Brilliancy prize (over both Tournaments): $40 book voucher at club bookshop
2026 Round-Robin Qualification

The winner of the Swiss qualifies to play in the 2026 MCC Classic Round-Robin tournament (subject to payment of applicable entry fee).
Should the winner decline to play, qualification will then pass on to the 2nd placegetter and then on to 3rd placegetter.
The tie-break method to determine rankings of placegetters will be the Buchholz method. The tie-break will be used only to rank players for the purpose of qualification into the 2025 MCC Classic Round-Robin.

title.en-US: Victorian Junior Chess Championship 2025 Concludes with Thrilling Victories

summary.en-US: The 2025 Victorian Junior Chess Championship was held from 17 to 20 July 2025 at Bacchus Marsh Grammar, Woodlea Campus, proudly hosted by the Hobsons Bay and Wyndham Chess Clubs

content.en-US:
The 2025 Victorian Junior Chess Championship was held from 17 to 20 July 2025 at Bacchus Marsh Grammar, Woodlea Campus, proudly hosted by the Hobsons Bay and Wyndham Chess Clubs. Spanning multiple divisions—U8, U10, U12, U14, U16 and U18, each with Open and Girls sections—the tournament assembled the most promising youthful talents from across Victoria.

In the U16–U18 Open, the top podium was fiercely contested. Ultimately, Wang Cunmeng clinched first with 6.5 points, closely followed by Candidate Master Arthur Gao on 6, and Candidate Master Tedric Li with 5.5.

The U14 Open division saw Neev Brahmbhatt dominate with 6.5 points, while Anh Kiet Nguyen took a strong second place on 6.

In the U12 Open, Lucas Zhao emerged as champion with a perfect 7 points, ahead of Fergus Tang (6) and Matthew Zheng (6).

The Girls U16–U18 division showcased an impressive performance by Vidushi Dissanayake, who achieved a flawless 7/7 score.

Meanwhile, in the younger categories, Erin Yuan topped the U10 Girls with 7 points, Harry Wilford secured victory in U10 Open with 6.5, and Mia Tan reigned supreme in U8 Girls with a perfect 7-point performance.

Organizers reported a smoothly run, ACF-rated seven-round Swiss event, with time controls tailored to each age group—U8 and U10 played under a 40 min + 10 sec increment format.

This year’s Championship not only celebrated standout performances but also tremendous sportsmanship and potential among Victoria’s young chess stars.

summary.en-US: Chess parents and aspiring young players, it’s time to mark your calendars! The much-anticipated 2025 Victorian Junior Rapid Chess Championship is fast approaching

content.en-US:
Chess parents and aspiring young players, it’s time to mark your calendars! The much-anticipated 2025 Victorian Junior Rapid Chess Championship is fast approaching — and this is your chance to ignite a passion for chess, develop critical skills, and be part of an exciting, competitive community.

Event Details at a Glance

Date: Sunday, 21 September 2025

Registration: Opens at 11:00 AM; gameplay starts at 12:00 PM

Venue: Glen Waverley Secondary College (O’Sullivan Road, Glen Waverley, VIC)

Format: 7-round Swiss

Time control: 13 minutes per player, with a 2-second increment per move from move one

Divisions: Open and Girls categories

Why Junior Chess Matters — and Why You Should Join
For Parents

Builds confidence and focus: Rapid chess fosters thoughtful decision-making under pressure.

Encourages healthy competition: Kids meet peers who share their interests, building friendships and sportsmanship.

Supports learning: Wins or losses, every game is a chance to reflect and grow.

For Young Players

Fast-paced excitement: 13+2 time controls keep adrenaline high — every move matters!

A stepping stone to bigger titles: Shine here and aim for state and national events.

Trophies, medals, and bragging rights: Represent your school and show off your skills.

What You Can Do Next

Register early — spots fill fast!

Parents: pack snacks, water, and encourage rest before games.

Kids: warm up with a few rapid games to get in the groove.

Stay connected: Many players join friends or clubs afterward for more chess fun.

Final Word

Whether your child is new to chess or already sharpening their tactical game, the 2025 Victorian Junior Rapid Chess Championship is the perfect stage to play, learn, and enjoy the thrill of competition.

Ready, set… checkmate! See you at the boards on Sunday, 21 September.

content.value: Chess is more than just a game of strategy; it is a discipline that cultivates patience, foresight, creativity, and resilience. At Chess Victoria, our mission is to harness the transformative power of chess to inspire individuals, connect communities, and build a culture of learning and achievement that extends far beyond the 64 squares of the board. We believe chess is not only a sport but also an educational tool, a social bridge, and a lifelong pursuit that strengthens both the mind and character.

Chess Victoria was founded on the conviction that everyone, regardless of age, background, or ability, should have the opportunity to explore the joys and challenges of chess. Through our programs, tournaments, workshops, and community initiatives, we aim to cultivate a thriving ecosystem where chess becomes an instrument of empowerment and excellence.
Our Core Mission
The central mission of Chess Victoria is to
promote chess as a sport, educational resource, and cultural activity
throughout our communities. This mission rests on three interwoven pillars:
inclusivity, development, and excellence.
Inclusivity

– We are committed to ensuring that chess is accessible to all people, regardless of gender, age, ability, or socio-economic background. By breaking down barriers to participation, we create pathways for anyone who wishes to engage with the game.
Development

– We seek to nurture players at every stage of their chess journey. From beginners learning the basics to advanced competitors aspiring for international titles, we provide the resources, mentorship, and opportunities needed for growth.
Excellence

– While inclusivity and development are essential, we also champion the pursuit of excellence. We believe that fostering a culture of achievement helps inspire the next generation of players and strengthens our reputation on the global chess stage.
Chess as Education

At the heart of our mission is the recognition of chess as an educational powerhouse. Studies consistently show that learning chess improves problem-solving skills, memory, concentration, and creativity. Chess also teaches discipline, patience, and sportsmanship—qualities that extend far beyond the board.

Through our school outreach programs, Chess Victoria partners with educators to integrate chess into curricula and after-school activities. By training teachers, hosting interschool tournaments, and providing digital resources, we bring chess to classrooms across the region. Our goal is not only to create stronger chess players but to foster sharper thinkers and lifelong learners.
Building a Chess Community

Chess thrives when it is shared. Chess Victoria envisions a community where players, coaches, parents, and supporters come together to celebrate the game. We organize local clubs, social meet-ups, and inclusive events where newcomers and veterans alike can enjoy chess in a welcoming environment.

Our tournaments range from friendly competitions to state championships, ensuring that every player—whether casual or competitive—has a place to shine. Beyond the board, our community is built on values of respect, camaraderie, and mutual growth. We see chess as a vehicle for forming friendships, bridging cultural differences, and fostering a sense of belonging.
Supporting Competitive Chess

While accessibility and community are at the core of our mission, we also recognize the importance of developing elite talent. Chess Victoria provides pathways for players to advance from grassroots levels to state, national, and even international competition. We support promising players with mentorship, training opportunities, and resources to pursue professional chess careers.

By hosting official tournaments, ranking players, and partnering with national and international federations, Chess Victoria contributes to the competitive structure that allows our players to thrive. We take pride in preparing athletes who represent our community with distinction on the global stage.
Empowering Coaches and Volunteers

A strong chess culture depends not only on players but also on dedicated mentors, coaches, and volunteers. Chess Victoria invests in training programs that equip coaches with modern teaching methods, ensuring that players of all levels receive quality instruction.

Our volunteers, too, are at the heart of our mission. From organizing events to mentoring young players, their contributions embody the spirit of service that sustains our community. We are committed to providing recognition, support, and development opportunities to all those who give their time and expertise to advance chess.
Promoting Inclusivity and Diversity

Chess Victoria is committed to breaking down barriers and championing diversity in all its forms. Historically, chess has been male-dominated, and certain communities have had limited access to the game. Our mission is to change this narrative by actively supporting programs that empower women, girls, and underrepresented groups to engage with chess.

Through scholarships, targeted outreach, and mentorship initiatives, we aim to create a chess environment where everyone feels welcome and valued. We envision a future where chess is a truly universal language, open to all voices and perspectives.
Chess and Technology

In today’s digital age, chess is undergoing a renaissance. Online platforms, interactive learning tools, and digital tournaments have expanded the reach of the game beyond physical boundaries. Chess Victoria embraces technology as a means to connect with broader audiences and innovate the way chess is taught and played.

We are committed to leveraging online platforms to provide accessible lessons, virtual competitions, and digital resources. By embracing both traditional and modern methods, we ensure that chess remains relevant, engaging, and inclusive for the next generation.
Long-Term Vision

Chess Victoria’s mission is not confined to the present—it is also deeply invested in the future. We envision a society where chess is integrated into schools, celebrated in public spaces, and recognized as a powerful force for intellectual and social development.
Our long-term vision includes:
Establishing a
Chess Academy
that serves as a hub for training, research, and innovation.
Expanding
statewide school programs
to reach every district.
Building partnerships with governments, corporations, and cultural organizations to enhance the visibility of chess.
Elevating local players to international recognition, creating role models for future generations.
Conclusion

The mission of Chess Victoria is clear: to promote, develop, and celebrate chess as a sport, an educational tool, and a unifying cultural activity. We strive to make chess accessible to all, nurture talent at every level, and foster a thriving community built on values of respect, inclusion, and excellence.

Chess Victoria believes that when we empower individuals through chess, we empower communities. When we encourage strategic thinking, resilience, and creativity, we prepare people for success not only in the game but in life itself.
Through every move, every tournament, and every new initiative, we carry forward the vision of a vibrant, inclusive, and enduring chess culture. That is our mission—and our promise.

summary.en-US: Chess Victoria’s vision is to establish chess as a cornerstone of intellectual growth, social connection, and cultural enrichment in every community we touch.

content.value: A vision is more than a statement of ambition; it is a compass that guides every initiative, decision, and action. At Chess Victoria, our vision extends beyond the immediate goals of tournaments and training. We imagine a future where chess is not just a pastime or a competitive pursuit, but a vital cultural and educational force woven into the fabric of society.

Our vision provides a horizon to work toward: a world where chess is celebrated for its intellectual beauty, embraced for its inclusivity, and recognized as a pathway to personal and communal excellence. It is about creating an enduring legacy that transcends the game itself.
The Essence of Our Vision
Chess Victoria’s vision is
to establish chess as a cornerstone of intellectual growth, social connection, and cultural enrichment in every community we touch.
This vision encompasses three fundamental aspirations:
A Culture of Chess

– We aspire to create a society where chess is as common and celebrated as other sports and arts. Chess will be visible in schools, workplaces, libraries, community centers, and online platforms—an integral part of daily life.
Global Recognition and Excellence
– We envision local players rising to prominence on the international stage, becoming role models who inspire future generations and showcase the strength of our chess culture to the world.
Chess for All Generations

– Our vision is inclusive and lifelong. From young children discovering the game for the first time, to seniors sharpening their minds and enjoying social connections, chess will be a companion through every stage of life.
Chess as a Universal Language

One of the core elements of our vision is the recognition of chess as a universal language. It transcends age, culture, gender, and geography. In a world often divided by differences, chess provides a common ground where individuals can connect, compete, and collaborate.

We see a future where Chess Victoria contributes to building bridges between diverse communities. Through cultural exchanges, international collaborations, and cross-generational programs, chess will become a medium of unity and understanding.
Chess in Education

Our vision places a strong emphasis on the role of chess in education. We imagine a future where chess is not an optional extracurricular, but a widely integrated educational tool used to develop critical skills.
In schools
, chess will be part of the curriculum, enhancing problem-solving, critical thinking, and emotional intelligence.
For educators
, chess will serve as a versatile resource for teaching patience, planning, and resilience.
For students
, it will provide a fun yet challenging way to strengthen their minds, preparing them for academic and personal success.
In this vision, every child will have the opportunity to learn chess, regardless of their background or circumstances.
A Thriving Chess Community

Our vision extends to building a chess culture that is vibrant, inclusive, and self-sustaining. We see thriving local clubs in every district, bustling with activity, and accessible to players of all levels.
Casual players will find social spaces to enjoy the game with friends.
Competitive players will find structured pathways to develop and test their skills.
Families will find chess to be a shared activity that strengthens bonds.
In this community, every member—players, coaches, organizers, volunteers, and supporters—will feel valued and connected. Chess will no longer be a solitary pursuit but a collective celebration.
Excellence on the Global Stage

Our vision is not limited to grassroots development; it extends to the international chess arena. We imagine a future where Chess Victoria is recognized as a hub of talent and innovation, producing world-class players who compete at the highest levels.

These players will not only represent our region with pride but also inspire future generations to believe in their own potential. Our vision includes creating training academies, mentorship networks, and financial support systems that empower ambitious players to pursue professional chess careers.
Empowering Diversity
A central element of our vision is inclusivity. We aspire to create a chess culture that actively supports and uplifts underrepresented groups.
For women and girls
, our vision includes a thriving pipeline of participation, leadership, and representation at every level of the game.
For marginalized communities
, we envision targeted outreach programs that ensure chess is accessible as a tool of empowerment.
For people of all abilities
, we see chess as a universally adaptable activity that welcomes everyone, regardless of physical or cognitive differences.
Our vision is a world where the phrase “chess is for everyone” is not aspirational but a lived reality.
Chess and Technology
The digital era presents unprecedented opportunities for chess. In our vision, Chess Victoria embraces technology not as a replacement for traditional play but as a complementary force.
We see a future where:
Players can seamlessly compete in both in-person and online tournaments.
Learning resources are available digitally, making high-quality chess education accessible to anyone with an internet connection.
Online platforms allow players from remote areas to connect with broader chess communities.
This vision positions Chess Victoria at the forefront of innovation, ensuring chess remains relevant and engaging for generations to come.
Building Institutions and Legacy

Our vision includes the establishment of lasting institutions that secure the future of chess. A Chess Victoria Academy, research initiatives on chess and cognitive science, partnerships with universities, and permanent community chess centers are all part of this long-term dream.

By investing in institutions, we create a legacy that continues to serve players, educators, and communities long after the present generation. These institutions will stand as symbols of our commitment to excellence and longevity.
A Global Model

Finally, our vision extends beyond regional boundaries. We aspire to make Chess Victoria a model for other chess organizations around the world. Through best practices in inclusivity, education, and community building, we hope to inspire and collaborate with international partners.
In this future, Chess Victoria will not only serve its immediate community but also contribute to the global growth of chess as a force for good.
Conclusion

Chess Victoria’s vision is bold, ambitious, and deeply human. It is a vision of chess not as a niche hobby but as a powerful tool for education, connection, and cultural enrichment. It is a vision of thriving communities, inspired players, and enduring institutions.

We see a world where chess is woven into the daily lives of people from all walks of life. A world where local talent shines globally. A world where diversity is celebrated, technology is embraced, and education is enriched through the game.
Most importantly, we see a future where chess is more than a game—it is a way of thinking, a way of connecting, and a way of living. That is the vision of Chess Victoria.
